channel.title: Blog on Zain Rizvi
channel.description: Recent content in Blog on Zain Rizvi

item.title: Want to make a feature change to PyTorch?
item.description: With such a large number of commits coming in, PyTorch needs a process for managing it all to keep the codebase maintainable. For smaller changes, like a five line bug fix, this takes the form of a regular PR review. For larger changes, we prefer a Request for Comments

item.title: The Software Engineer's Career Ladder
item.description: What’s expected of you when you’re a junior, senior, or staff software engineer, and what it takes to rise up in the ranks.

item.title: Insider's Guide to Passing FAANG Interviews
item.description: My 12+ years as both the interviewer and interviewee at Google, Microsoft, and Stripe taught me one thing: Standard interviewing advice falls woefully short. Grinding interview questions isn’t enough. Here’s what to do.

item.title: PARA vs Zettelkasten: The false binary
item.description:
I started practicing PARA and Zettelkasten two years ago. Here’s what I’ve realized after twenty four months of practice:

Change the system, not yourself

There’s a common mistake people made when following popular note taking or productivity systems, be it PARA, Zettelkasten, GTD, Bullet Journals, or anything else.

They assume each system is universal.

Those systems weren’t built for mass consumption. Rather, their inventors had each felt a gap in their own abilities, where their previous systems didn’t match their personalities. Like two jigsaw pieces that don’t quite fit.

item.title: Why Software Engineers like Woodworking
item.description:
The smell of fresh pine sawdust filled the air, with more floating up as I sanded the last rough corner of the stool. My toddler was happily sanding her own block off to the side.

Woodworking was a new hobby I’d picked up. My old ones, coding, reading, writing, had kept me stuck to my laptop, holed up by myself. Not very toddler friendly.

A surprise gift laid the seeds of an idea. As a boy, the best summer days were when my dad and I would transform scratch wood into bird houses, planes, and eventually even rube goldberg devices. It was time to rekindle the flame.

item.title: Your confusion is the litmus test
item.description:
I was fumbling in the dark. Groping blindly.

It seemed so much simpler a month ago.

“Hey, could you integrate this tool into our service?” my manager had asked. “Sure,” I’d replied. “How hard could it be?”

Famous last words.

Now it was my job to take this convoluted piece of security infrastructure, which I knew nothing about, which itself was still under active development, and wrangle it into submission.

It’s just code, right?

item.title: How to slay a Hydra: Finishing projects
item.description: This project was supposed to be easy, why do I keep running into brick walls?!? Ok, how do I work around this one without compromising my vision?

item.title: Falsehoods programmers believe about time zones
item.description: I decided to make a time zone converter. It had seemed like an easy project, but I was horribly mistaken

item.title: How banks help scammers with their bad UI
item.description: My sister wanted a summer job before starting college. Instead she was scammed out of thousands

item.title: Never Focus on the User
item.description: User focused design is wasteful. Every business knows this, but they’re afraid to admit it. It’s is a PR friendly way to say they focus on their buyers

item.title: You're all set
item.description:
There’s a welcome email waiting in your inbox with your salary negotiation tips

I won’t hide it, I’m excited to have you onboard üòÄ

Enjoy!

item.title: Taking my own Advice
item.description:
You‚Äôve heard how the best way to learn is by teaching, right?

Wrong.

Try grading instead. The single biggest practice that improved my writing was reviewing other people’s essays. David Perell made me do it.

I took his class Write of Passage, and on the very first day we were told to write an essay. And give feedback.

To random strangers.

About their essays.

That didn‚Äôt seem right.

He expected me to give advice? Wasn‚Äôt he the teacher? I wasn‚Äôt qualified to do this, I barely knew how to write my own. That‚Äôs why I was taking the class!

item.title: How I learned to turn Impostor Syndrome into an Advantage - The Impostor's Advantage
item.description: My heart was racing. My palms sweating. I was going to be fired. Performance reviews had just ended, and it was time to meet my manager and be told my results. Except I knew what it would say. How else do you rate a programmer who doesn‚Äôt code?

item.title: I couldn‚Äôt abandon another side project
item.description: I didn’t want this to become another abandoned project. By trying to do less stuff, I got more done

item.title: Effective Altruism is Suboptimal
item.description: What a homeless cametaught me about caring for others

item.title: Dangerous Professionals: Hacking the Bureaucracy to Get Stuff Done
item.description: The Dangerous Professional finds the seams between the policies, and slips inside them to Get Stuff Done

item.title: Welcome to the Newsletter!
item.description:
There’s a welcome email waiting in your inbox üòÄ

So what can you expect? I’ll be sending you an email no more than once a week sharing the most interesting lessons I learn.

Enjoy!

item.title: What's it like as a Senior Engineer at Google?
item.description:
When I started working at Microsoft, fresh out of college, coding was my life. Writing code was the easiest way to build any cool thing that my brain could imagine. When I thought about what I‚Äôd want to do for the rest of my life I thought that I just wanted to keep coding.

I was wrong

item.title: Interview advice that got me offers from Google, Microsoft, and Stripe
item.description:
‚ÄúWhat would you say if I asked you to design me a service capable of responding to thousands of user requests every second and latency was critical?‚Äù

‚ÄúUmm…that you have to solve this problem at work. But you‚Äôre out of ideas, and are looking to interviewees for suggestions‚Äù

That‚Äôs the actual response I gave the interviewer the first time I was asked a design question. He had a good laugh. But then still made me design the service.

item.title: Remembering what you Read: Zettelkasten vs P.A.R.A.
item.description: I spent over a year researching better ways to take notes and remember what I read. Here’s what I found.

item.title: Quickly Building Products for ACTUAL Customers
item.description:
This is my tweetstorm on key aspects to focus on when you‚Äôre building a SaaS service. It details how features that seem critical may not actually be that important. Experiment to see what your actual customers are demanding, and focus 100% of your effort on that. It‚Äôs okay to acquire technical debt along the way

1/ @Google SREs released a free book on Building Secure and Reliable Systemshttps://t.co/qr725ptjpQ

It's a great book, but not all the requirements of a huge international company with 100,000 employees will apply to your company

Carefully pick & choose what's relevant to you

item.title: The Truth about VPC Security Controls
item.description:
GCP‚Äôs VPC Service Controls protection is often described as a virtual firewall for your GCP projects. That‚Äôs a useful mental model for your company‚Äôs decision makers to think with, but the analogy quickly breaks down if you‚Äôre an engineer trying to actually implement VPC-SC protection for your GCP projects.

I learned that the hard way.

Here I‚Äôll describe just what VPC-SC is, why it was needed, and a big mistake I made which you reeeally want to make sure you avoid.

item.title: So you want to do Deep Work?
item.description: In this information era where all mechanical tasks are being automated, in order to be successful you need to be able to do what machines cannot: be creative. And creativity is something you can generate on demand through deep work, and in his book ‚ÄúDeep Work‚Äù Cal explains how you can achieve it.

item.title: How to setup a Free Custom Domain Email Address
item.description:
I recently discovered that it‚Äôs possible to combine any domain that you own with your Gmail account and a free MailGun account to get a free custom domain email address!

When you‚Äôre done following the below instructions you‚Äôll be able to send and receive emails addressed to you@yourdomain.com directly from your Gmail inbox.

Step 1 - Buy a domain

Okay, so you still have to pay to own your domain, but the rest is free. And if you want a custom domain email address, then chances are you‚Äôre interested in your professional reputation. Owning your own domain is a good idea even if you don‚Äôt plan to start your own sure just yet. I held off on it a couple years and that was enough for a law student to grab zainrizvi.com -_-

item.title: How to Create Customized Deep Learning Containers
item.description:
Ever find yourself needing to install the same packages on all your deep learning notebooks? Or maybe wishing you could send your exact setup to someone else who could run your notebook? Or perhaps you‚Äôre a corporation which wants all your data scientists to have some internal libraries on all their notebooks.

Turns out you can. GCP‚Äôs AI Platform Notebooks team offers Deep Learning Containers, which is a containerized version of the exact same images you get when you create a regular AI Platform Notebook (full disclosure: that‚Äôs my team).

item.title: How to Use GPUs with R in Jupyter Lab
item.description:
Have you ever tried installing drivers for your Nvidia GPUs? The first time I tried, I spent the better half of an afternoon trying to get that done.

And once I realized I also had to recompile multiple packages to actually use those GPUs, I was one error message away from being this guy:

Things have gotten a lot better since then.

In this post I‚Äôll share an easy way to setup your R language Jupyter Notebooks to use GPUs. (Though if you prefer to use R outside of a notebook, these steps let you do that too)

item.title: The Essential Git Cheat Sheet
item.description:
Quick cheat sheet of commonly used git commands that I‚Äôd otherwise have to keep Googling to remember

Rebase your branch to the latest master

If your current branch was branched off of master and you want to pull the latest updates pushed to master since then:

git pull --rebase origin master

Pull a branch other than the one you’re on

For example, if you’re not on the master branch but want to pull and merge master

item.title: Use Virtual Environments Inside Jupyter Notebooks & Jupter Lab [Best Practices]
Authenticating AI Platform Notebooks against BigQuery in Python
item.description:
When you use AI Platform Notebooks by default any API calls you make to GCP use the default compute service account that your notebook runs under. This makes it easy to start getting stuff done, but sometimes you may want to use BigQuery to query data that your service account doesn‚Äôt have access to.

The below instructions describe how to use your personal account to authenticate with BigQuery. This specifically applies to authentication when using a python based notebook. If you want to authenticate on a R based notebook you can find instructions for that here.

item.title: Become Creative by Asking Better Questions
item.description:
These are the key lessons I discovered while reading Warren Berger‚Äôs A More Beautiful Question. Most material is directly from the book with a few of my own ideas interspersed

Why do we need to ask questions?

The economic model of the world is shifting. The nature of knowledge, work, and employment is changing.

  • What business are we in now?
  • Will my jobs still be needed in a few years?
  • Is ‚Äúknowing‚Äù obsolete in the age of Google?
  • How do you move from asking to action?

The Power of Inquiry: Asking questions is now more important than knowing

item.title: So Good They Can't Ignore You - Key Ideas
item.description:
These are my notes from Cal Newport‚Äôs book So Good They Can‚Äôt Ignore You: Why Skills Trump Passion in the Quest for Work You Love

I‚Äôm going to skip the persuasive arguments that Cal listed and jump straight to the conclusions that resonated with me

Value your Autonomy

‚ÄúFind your Passion‚Äù is a lie. That‚Äôs not how humans work

Reality: We become passionate about any work that can meet certain requirements

item.title: Using BigRQuery on GCP AI Platform Notebooks
item.description:
Note: These instructions can be used whenever you‚Äôre using Jupyter Lab on a remote machine

GCP AI Platform Notebooks makes it really easy to run notebooks on Jupyter Lab and even offers R language notebooks. R is great for crunching large data sets, and a popular place for people to store their data is on BigQuery.

The most popular library for accessing BigQuery in R is the open source library BigRQuery. It‚Äôs an extremely useful library, but it has the downside that the authentication step will try one of two things:

item.title: Five Tactics for Tackling Complex Problems at Work
item.description:
‚ÄúThe definition of genius is taking the complex and making it simple.‚Äù ‚ÄìAlbert Einstein

In today‚Äôs world the most valuable employees are the ones who can tackle complex problems. And the best of those are the ones who can make the complex problems look simple.

But how can someone actually do that? Below are some tactics I‚Äôve used which can make a big difference.

These tactics are designed to get me thinking about the problem space in different ways. The different perspectives often yield insights that help separate the core components into smaller, more manageable units (and of course this list is always a work in progress)

item.title: 5 Habits for Better Learning
item.description:
These mental habits were developed to teach school children how to think critically and become problems solvers. It‚Äôs a valuable skill for adults to learn as well.

When presented with any new information think about:

  1. Evidence: Why do you think this information is true or false? What should count? What do you think you know and why?
  2. Viewpoints: How would this look from other perspectives? How would other people or companies think about this differently?
  3. Connections: Noticing any patterns? Have you seen something like this before?
  4. Conjecture: What if something about this was different? How would that impact things?
  5. Relevance: Why does this matter?

(Source: A More Beautiful Question by Warren Berger)

item.title: Salary Negotiation Tips
How to: Redirect the default *.azurewebsites.net domain to your custom domain on Azure Web Apps
Deploy Statically Generated Sites with Yeoman
item.description:
There are a lot of awesome static site generators out there. It‚Äôs not always easy to figure out how to setup continuous deployment for them though.

This post will describe how to deploy a statically generated site using yeoman angular to Azure Web Apps, but these steps can be applied to deploy any statically generated site to Azure Web Apps.

Deploying the initial site

I tried using yeoman‚Äôs gulp-angular generator. I made a quick site following their tutorial, setup continuous deployment via github, navigated to the newly deployed site and I saw‚Ä¶huh?

item.title: Backup just the Important Parts of your Site with Azure Web Apps
item.description:
Introducting a way to backup just the parts of your website that matter most.

Introduction

Azure Web Apps provides powerful backup/restore functionality. (Because disasters can happen to anyone)

However, sometimes you don‚Äôt want to backup everything on your site, especially if you backup your site regularly, or if your site has over 10GB of content (that‚Äôs the max amount you can backup at a time).

For example, you probably don‚Äôt want to back up the log files. Or if you setup weekly backups you won‚Äôt want to fill up your storage account with static content that never changes like old blog posts or images.
